heading: 1.1.7 Vectors
text:
Vectors univariate data structures. Vectors can created using c() function 
elements separated commas.Note examplevar1 actually vector length 1.calling vectors Console, note numbers square brackets 
corresponding output represent position number first element line.

heading: 1.1.7.1 Extracting elements
text:
elements vectors can extracted supplying vector positive integers inside square
brackets. Note R, indices begin 1.

heading: 1.1.7.2 Deleting elements
text:
elements vectors can deleted supplying vector negative integers placing 
negative outside vector positive integers, inside square brackets.

heading: 1.1.8 Data frames
text:
Data frames multivariate data structures. Data frames can thought vertical
concatentation vectors. cases, column data frame contains values 
single variable row data frame contains values variable single
observation. example, consider following data set:example , column contains values single variable row contains
values variable single observation (patient).Things note:Data frames can created supplying name-value pairs data.frame() function.Name-value pairs supplied using = rather <-.name-value pair must length. Missing values can represented using NA.
code:
patients <- data.frame(
  patient_id = c("123abc", "28fnr8", "02jr8d", "r82j45", "t90ro5"),
  height = c(181, 145, 190, 210, 94),
  mass = c(85, 72, 82, 90, 60),
  sex = c("M", "F", "M", "F", "F")
)

patients##   patient_id height mass sex
## 1     123abc    181   85   M
## 2     28fnr8    145   72   F
## 3     02jr8d    190   82   M
## 4     r82j45    210   90   F
## 5     t90ro5     94   60   F

heading: 1.1.8.1 Extracting columns
text: Columns data frame can extracted vectors using dollar sign ($).
code:
patients$height## [1] 181 145 190 210  94
patients$sex## [1] "M" "F" "M" "F" "F"

heading: 1.1.8.2 Extracting rows and subsets
text:
Thinking data frames matrices, can subsetted supplying row column
positions/names separated comma within square brackets:
code:
# Extract row 3 and all columns
patients[3, ]##   patient_id height mass sex
## 3     02jr8d    190   82   M
# Extract rows 1, 4, and 5, and columns 1 and 3
patients[c(1, 4, 5), c(1, 3)]##   patient_id mass
## 1     123abc   85
## 4     r82j45   90
## 5     t90ro5   60
# Extract rows 1, 4, and 5, and columns "patient_id" and "mass"
patients[c(1, 4, 5), c("patient_id", "mass")]##   patient_id mass
## 1     123abc   85
## 4     r82j45   90
## 5     t90ro5   60
# Extract everything *except* rows 2 and 3, and columns 2 and 3
patients[-c(2, 3), -c(2, 3)]##   patient_id sex
## 1     123abc   M
## 4     r82j45   F
## 5     t90ro5   F

heading: 1.1.10 Paths
text:
path string (.e. needs surrounded quotes) describes location file 
folder device. Paths become extremely important reading writing files R. Paths
can broken two categories: absolute relative.

text:

assume identical folder structure root path.two helpers specifying relative paths: dot, ".", double-dot, "..".

text:
Assignment 1 Question 5, given data ordered pairs need manually

heading: 1.2.3 Fitting the SLR model
text:
Linear regression models fit using lm() function. first need fit model\[Y_{} \,=\, \beta_{0} \,+\, \beta_{1}X_{} \,+\, \varepsilon_{}, \quad =1,\ldots,n\]order determine whether\[Y_{} \,=\, \beta_{0} \,+\, \varepsilon_{}, \quad =1,\ldots,n\]appropriate model.code says build linear regression model using y dependent (response)
variable, x independent (predictor) variable, variables y x 
found within table1.1 data variable. Although need specify intercept 
formula specification, linear regression models built lm() include intercept default.
code: slr_model <- lm(y ~ x, data=table1.1)

heading: 1.2.4 Inspecting the model
text: can obtain summary linear regression model using summary() function.information , fitted regression line equation:\[\widehat{y}_{} \,=\, 13.62 \,-\, 0.08x_{} \quad =1,\ldots,n\]
code:
summary(slr_model)## 
## Call:
## lm(formula = y ~ x, data = table1.1)
## 
## Residuals:
##     Min      1Q  Median      3Q     Max 
## -1.6789 -0.5291 -0.1221  0.7988  1.3457 
## 
## Coefficients:
##             Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)    
## (Intercept) 13.62299    0.58146  23.429  < 2e-16 ***
## x           -0.07983    0.01052  -7.586 1.05e-07 ***
## ---
## Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1
## 
## Residual standard error: 0.8901 on 23 degrees of freedom
## Multiple R-squared:  0.7144, Adjusted R-squared:  0.702 
## F-statistic: 57.54 on 1 and 23 DF,  p-value: 1.055e-07

heading: 1.2.5 Is an intercept-only model appropriate?
text:
determine whether intercept-model appropriate, need test hypotheses:\[H_{0}: \beta_{1} \,=\, 0, \quad H_{}: \beta_{1} \,\neq\, 0\]value test statistic can read summary table value -7.586 
corresponding \(p\)-value 1.05e-07. Using significance level \(\alpha = 0.05\), since
\(p\)-value less \(\alpha\), reject null hypothesis conclude 
evidence support claim \(\beta_{1}\) different zero., consider intercept-model.\(p\)-value greater \(\alpha = 0.05\) failed reject null
hypothesis? fit intercept-model?Aside: note (Intercept) row, t-value \(p\)-value correspond testing 
hypotheses:\[H_{0}: \beta_{0} \,=\, 0, \quad H_{}: \beta_{0} \,\neq\, 0\]

heading: 1.2.6 The rock data set
text:
fit intercept-model, let us consider rock data set built R. data
set can loaded using:can preview data usual:

heading: 1.2.7 Fitting a SLR
text:
create simple linear regression model using area dependent (response) variable 
shape independent (predictor) variable.equation fitted line :\[\widehat{y}_{} \,=\, 8465 \,-\, 5855x_{}, \quad =1,\ldots,n\]Testing hypotheses:\[H_{0}: \beta_{1} \,=\, 0, \quad H_{}: \beta_{1} \,\neq\, 0\]corresponding \(p\)-value 0.215. Using significance level \(\alpha = 0.05\), since 
\(p\)-value greater 0.05, fail reject null hypothesis. , insufficient
evidence support claim \(\beta_{1}\) non-zero.Now fit intercept-model!
code:
rock_slr_model <- lm(area ~ shape, data=rock)

summary(rock_slr_model)## 
## Call:
## lm(formula = area ~ shape, data = rock)
## 
## Residuals:
##     Min      1Q  Median      3Q     Max 
## -6101.6 -1512.3   104.6  1765.3  5152.9 
## 
## Coefficients:
##             Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)    
## (Intercept)     8465       1087   7.788 6.08e-10 ***
## shape          -5855       4660  -1.256    0.215    
## ---
## Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1
## 
## Residual standard error: 2667 on 46 degrees of freedom
## Multiple R-squared:  0.03318,    Adjusted R-squared:  0.01216 
## F-statistic: 1.579 on 1 and 46 DF,  p-value: 0.2153

heading: 1.2.8 Fitting an intercept-only model
text:
One way fitting intercept-model use lm() .dependent (response) variable remains area, right-hand side formula just
1 indicate intercept.second way fitting intercept-model take advantage fact already
built simple linear regression model (rock_slr_model) obtain intercept-model 
just need "remove" shape variable formula specification. can accomplished
using update() function.formula specification , . refers "everything already ". ,
. left ~ refers area, . right ~ refers 
1 + shape (1 usually written since linear regression models fit 
intercept default, still exists!). Therefore, code says 
rock_intercept_model "update" rock_slr_model modification 
formula now area ~ 1 + shape - shape, resulting area ~ 1. can verify 
fact needed calling:update() function extremely useful start working multiple linear
regression models variable selection procedures later course sometimes
easier specify variables want rather ones want.output , equation fitted line :\[\widehat{y}_{} \,=\, 7187.7, \quad =1,\ldots,n\]
code:
rock_intercept_model <- lm(area ~ 1, data=rock)
rock_intercept_model <- update(rock_slr_model, formula = . ~ . - shape)
formula(rock_intercept_model)## area ~ 1
summary(rock_intercept_model)## 
## Call:
## lm(formula = area ~ 1, data = rock)
## 
## Residuals:
##     Min      1Q  Median      3Q     Max 
## -6171.7 -1882.5   299.3  1681.8  5024.3 
## 
## Coefficients:
##             Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)    
## (Intercept)   7187.7      387.4   18.55   <2e-16 ***
## ---
## Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1
## 
## Residual standard error: 2684 on 47 degrees of freedom

heading: 1.2.9 Visualising the intercept-only fit
text:
can draw scatterplot data area y-axis shape x-axis, 
overlay intercept-fit. drawing lines base-R graphics, recall need sort
x-values (reorder corresponding y-values)! example, since fitted values
constant values shape, need reorder fitted values 
corresponding shape values â€” shape values need sorted. However, 
sake consistency, sort shape values reorder corresponding fitted values.fitted values intercept-model can obtained wrapping model 
fitted() function.Now, making plot:

heading: 1.2.10.1 The residual vs. predictor plot
text:
identify potential issues intercept-model, can make plot residuals,
\(e_{} \,=\, Y_{} \,-\, \widehat{Y}_{}\), predictor values (shape).residual values intercept-model can obtained wrapping model 
resid() function.Now, making plot:assumptions linear regression, discernable patterns/trends 
plotted points. addition, plot look like random scatter \(y=0\) constant
variance. plot , appear patterns/trends 
plotted points. plot appears random scatter \(y=0\) constant variance.

heading: 1.2.10.2 The residual vs. fitted plot
text:
identify potential issues intercept-model, can also make plot residuals,
\(e_{} \,=\, Y_{} \,-\, \widehat{Y}_{}\), fitted values., discernable patterns/trends plotted points, plot
look like random scatter \(y=0\) constant variance. plot look bit
strange, fitted line constant! residuals appear scattered
\(y=0\) equal variance, seem issues .
code:
plot(
  resid(rock_intercept_model) ~ fitted(rock_intercept_model),
  main="Residuals vs Fitted", xlab="fitted values", ylab="residuals"
)

heading: 1.2.10.3 Normality of residuals
text:
also assumption residuals normally distributed. can checked 
creating QQ-plot residuals overlaying QQ-line.Strong deviation QQ-line evidence violation normality assumption. 
case plot, reason believe residuals 
normally distributed.
code:
qqnorm(resid(rock_intercept_model))
qqline(resid(rock_intercept_model), col="darkred", lwd=2)

heading: 2.1 Some modern data science packages
text:
Tidyverse collection packages modern data
science. Tidymodels another collection packages 
extends tidyverse modelling. labs, 
using entire tidyverse tidymodels. now, recommend installing 
component packages.tibble, dplyr,
ggplot2, broom. 
packages can installed using:successfully installing packages, can load using:Additionally, ggplot2 comes various plotting themes (examples
can found ). 
default, plotting background grey prefer white background also call:tibble package provides us usage "tibbles" 
extension base-R data frame. many features, mostly using tibbles
pretty-printing features 
fact integrates well packages.dplyr package provides us tools data wrangling 
base-R equivalents can feel bit clunky. Examples data wrangling include: adding/removing
observations based presence/absence one conditions, creating additional variables
data set, condensing existing data summaries.ggplot2 package alternative base-R graphics
functions "smarter" exist base-R. example, previous
lab, mentioned plotting lines base-R, points needed sorted left right
since lines() function joins points order appear. Without sorting, 
resulting line appear jagged unevenly coloured certain areas. 
ggplot2, separate functions joining points 
appear data joining points order left right.broom package contains tools cleaning model output 
extracting model data diagnostic information ready visualisation 
ggplot2.
code:
install.packages("tibble")
install.packages("dplyr")
install.packages("ggplot2")
install.packages("broom")
library(tibble)
library(dplyr)
library(ggplot2)
library(broom)
theme_set(theme_bw())

heading: 2.2.1 The mpg data set
text:
Consider fuel economy data set found ggplot2 package.
can load data set calling:Suppose interested fitting simple linear regression model highway miles per gallon
(hwy) response variable city miles per gallon (cty) predictor variable.
fitting model, check see linear relationship 
chosen variables.
code: data(mpg, package="ggplot2")

heading: 2.2.2 Check for a linear relationship
text:
create plot, use function ggplot.call ggplot can thought initialisation drawing canvasThe first argument ggplot data set, mpgThe second argument ggplot mapping, .e. "variables contain data 
interested plotting?"mapping created supplying names variables found within data set 
aesthetics function, aes().Finally, can add ("plus" symbol) layer points geom_point() inherit
aesthetics supplied initialisation canvasIn words, specified within geom_point(), points drawn positions
x=cty y=hwyFrom plot , appears linear relationship two variables. can
begin fitting linear model.
code:
ggplot(mpg, aes(x=cty, y=hwy))+
  geom_point()

heading: 2.2.3 Fitting the linear model
text:
regression output, \(\widehat{\beta}_{0} = 0.892\) 
\(\widehat{\beta}_{1} = 1.337\). equation fitted line :\[\widehat{y}_{} \,=\, 0.892 \,+\, 1.337x_{}\]can interpret \(\widehat{\beta}_{0} = 0.892\) mean highway miles per gallon city
miles per gallon value zero. However, really make sense context 
data since car travels zero city miles gallon gas.can interpret \(\widehat{\beta}_{1} = 1.337\) mean change highway miles per gallon per
unit increase city miles per gallon. , 1 mpg increase city mpg, expect 1.337
mpg increase highway mpg.
code:
lm_miles <- lm(hwy ~ cty, data=mpg)

summary(lm_miles)## 
## Call:
## lm(formula = hwy ~ cty, data = mpg)
## 
## Residuals:
##     Min      1Q  Median      3Q     Max 
## -5.3408 -1.2790  0.0214  1.0338  4.0461 
## 
## Coefficients:
##             Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)    
## (Intercept)  0.89204    0.46895   1.902   0.0584 .  
## cty          1.33746    0.02697  49.585   <2e-16 ***
## ---
## Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1
## 
## Residual standard error: 1.752 on 232 degrees of freedom
## Multiple R-squared:  0.9138, Adjusted R-squared:  0.9134 
## F-statistic:  2459 on 1 and 232 DF,  p-value: < 2.2e-16

heading: 2.2.4 Visualising the fit
text:
ggplot2 broom
shine! first use broom::augment() linear model extract data used 
fit model, along additional diagnostics (residuals). Note 
broom::augment() generic function. pass lm object broom::augment(), 
hood, actually calls specific broom::augment.lm() function.first two columns lm_miles_aug, recovered data initially passed
lm(). .fitted column contains fitted values model .resid column
contains raw residuals.plot wish build use newly created lm_miles_aug data set 
following features:base plot scatterplot points located x=cty y=hwyThe fitted line drawn top points located x=cty y=.fittedSince points lines wish draw longer share common y-aesthetic, may 
want declare y-aesthetic initialisation canvas, instead, declare 
y-aesthetic individual layers.Notice building plot, sort points! default, geom_line()
connects points left right. added additional arguments geom_line() outside
aesthetics since values depend data:colour controls colour line (can also use color)lwd controls width line (can also use linewidth)alpha controls transparency lineTo see construction plot "addition layers" can runfollowed byfollowed

heading: 2.2.5.1 Confidence intervals
text:
Suppose interested finding point estimate 95% confidence interval mean
highway miles per gallon vehicles city miles per gallon value 20. can obtain 
values using predict() function. predict() another example generic function. 
pass lm object predict(), actually calls specific predict.lm() function.
see need get point estimate confidence interval, pull associated
documentation.need supply predict():linear model objectA data frame containing variables common linear model, values upon predict
Note model predictor variable cty, supply
newdata = data.frame(x=20), must supply newdata = data.frame(cty=20)
Note model predictor variable cty, supply
newdata = data.frame(x=20), must supply newdata = data.frame(cty=20)want confidence interval, specify interval = "confidence"default confidence level 0.95From output, point estimate 27.641. lower bound 95% confidence interval
27.360 upper bound 27.922. says 95% confidence, vehicles 
city miles per gallon value 20, mean highway miles per gallon range 27.360 
27.922.
code:
?predict.lm
predict(
  lm_miles,
  newdata = data.frame(cty=20),
  interval = "confidence"
)##        fit      lwr      upr
## 1 27.64115 27.36044 27.92187

heading: 2.2.5.2 Prediction intervals
text:
Suppose now interested finding point estimate 95% prediction interval 
highway miles per gallon vehicle city miles per gallon 20. can obtain 
values manner similar previous example:output, point estimate 27.641. lower bound 95% prediction interval
24.177 upper bound 31.105. says 95% confidence, vehicle city
miles per gallon value 20 highway miles per gallon value 24.177 31.105.
code:
predict(
  lm_miles,
  newdata = data.frame(cty=20),
  interval = "prediction"
)##        fit      lwr      upr
## 1 27.64115 24.17733 31.10498

heading: 2.2.5.3 Spot the differences
text:
point estimates cases identical. However, lower upper bounds 
confidence prediction intervals different. unsurprising since formulas used 
compute bounds two intervals different.noted , general, fixed confidence level, prediction interval 
wider corresponding confidence interval.

heading: 2.2.6 Correlations
text:
Using previously obtained augmented model data (lm_miles_aug), can easily obtain 
correlations \(X_{}\) \(Y_{}\),\(Y_{}\) \(\widehat{Y}_{}\),\(X_{}\) \(\widehat{Y}_{}\),compare among , compare model's coefficient determination,
\(R^{2}\). Correlations obtained using cor() function. also use summarise()
function dplyr package help us obtain correlations
staying context augmented data can reference variables using bare
names (.e. need use $ reference variables).Note also :values mathematically related coincidence? ðŸ˜² (See assignment 2
question 3).
code:
summarise(
  lm_miles_aug,
  corr_x_y = cor(cty, hwy),
  corr_y_fitted = cor(hwy, .fitted),
  corr_x_fitted = cor(cty, .fitted)
)## # A tibble: 1 x 3
##   corr_x_y corr_y_fitted corr_x_fitted
##      <dbl>         <dbl>         <dbl>
## 1    0.956         0.956             1

summarise(
  lm_miles_aug,
  corr_x_y_squared = cor(cty, hwy)^2,
  corr_y_fitted_squared = cor(hwy, .fitted)^2,
  corr_x_fitted_squared = cor(cty, .fitted)^2,
  r.squared = summary(lm_miles)$r.squared
)## # A tibble: 1 x 4
##   corr_x_y_squared corr_y_fitted_squared corr_x_fitted_squared r.squared
##              <dbl>                 <dbl>                 <dbl>     <dbl>
## 1            0.914                 0.914                     1     0.914

heading: 2.3 Simple linear regression with transformations
text:
applying transformations variables linear models, two options:Create new variable data set applies transformation, orApply transformation formula specificationTo observe differences, build two models using methods. Using mpg data set
, let us fit model response engine displacement predictor 
(natural) log highway miles per gallon.

heading: 2.3.1 Creating a new variable in your data set
text:
dplyr loaded, can easily create new variables data set using mutate()
function. first argument mutate() data set. Additional arguments name-value
pairs variables want create.model created usual:
code:
mpg2 <- mutate(
  mpg,
  log_hwy = log(hwy)
)
lm_displ1 <- lm(displ ~ log_hwy, data=mpg2)

heading: 2.3.2 Applying the transformation in the formula specification
text:
can apply transformations formula specification wish create new
variable ahead time. model created using:
code: lm_displ2 <- lm(displ ~ log(hwy), data=mpg2)

heading: 2.3.3 Comparing our two models
text:
models identical! try predict engine displacement vehicle 
highway miles per gallon value 29.predicted values different! ?models use variables created ahead time, value(s) supplied predict upon
must scale predictor values used fitting model.
words, supplying value 29 first model, predicting engine displacement
vehicle log highway miles per gallon value 29! order properly predict 
engine displacement, must instead supply value log(29).models transformations applied formula specification, can supply values 
original scale transformation applied us calculating predicted value.
code:
summary(lm_displ1)## 
## Call:
## lm(formula = displ ~ log_hwy, data = mpg2)
## 
## Residuals:
##     Min      1Q  Median      3Q     Max 
## -1.2992 -0.5548 -0.1148  0.4252  3.7446 
## 
## Coefficients:
##             Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)    
## (Intercept)  15.4145     0.6496   23.73   <2e-16 ***
## log_hwy      -3.8260     0.2074  -18.45   <2e-16 ***
## ---
## Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1
## 
## Residual standard error: 0.8243 on 232 degrees of freedom
## Multiple R-squared:  0.5946, Adjusted R-squared:  0.5929 
## F-statistic: 340.3 on 1 and 232 DF,  p-value: < 2.2e-16
summary(lm_displ2)## 
## Call:
## lm(formula = displ ~ log(hwy), data = mpg2)
## 
## Residuals:
##     Min      1Q  Median      3Q     Max 
## -1.2992 -0.5548 -0.1148  0.4252  3.7446 
## 
## Coefficients:
##             Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)    
## (Intercept)  15.4145     0.6496   23.73   <2e-16 ***
## log(hwy)     -3.8260     0.2074  -18.45   <2e-16 ***
## ---
## Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1
## 
## Residual standard error: 0.8243 on 232 degrees of freedom
## Multiple R-squared:  0.5946, Adjusted R-squared:  0.5929 
## F-statistic: 340.3 on 1 and 232 DF,  p-value: < 2.2e-16
predict(
  lm_displ1,
  newdata = data.frame(log_hwy=29)
)##         1 
## -95.53829
predict(
  lm_displ2,
  newdata = data.frame(hwy=29)
)##       1 
## 2.53138
predict(
  lm_displ1,
  newdata = data.frame(log_hwy=log(29))
)##       1 
## 2.53138

heading: 2.3.4 Warning â—
text:
operations applied formula specification treated mathematical
operations. example, + formula specification means add variable saw
section 1.2.8, - means remove variable. addition, ^ symbol usually use
exponentiation different meaning used formula specification. example, 
wanted fit model using square highway miles per gallon predictor, 
write:Instead, must either create variable ahead time wrap exponentiation ():operation wrapped () formula specification, means treat literal
mathematical operator rather formula operator.
code:
lm(displ ~ hwy^2, data=mpg2)
lm(displ ~ I(hwy^2), data=mpg2)

heading: 2.4 Another example
text:
sake illustration, suppose wish fit model response variable 
log highway miles per gallon plus log city miles per gallon predictor
variable square engine displacement. create response variable ahead
time apply transformation predictor formula specification.model fitted using:equation fitted line :\[\widehat{y}_{} \,=\, 6.445 \,-\, 0.039x_{}^{2}\]\(\widehat{y}_{}\) sum log highway miles per gallon log city miles per
gallon. Due model constructed, wanted predict sum log highway
miles per gallon log city highway miles per gallon particular vehicle, supply
displacement values -model square .
code:
mpg2 <- mutate(
  mpg2,
  mpg_sum = log(hwy) + log(cty)
)
lm_log_miles <- lm(mpg_sum ~ I(displ^2), data=mpg2)

summary(lm_log_miles)## 
## Call:
## lm(formula = mpg_sum ~ I(displ^2), data = mpg2)
## 
## Residuals:
##      Min       1Q   Median       3Q      Max 
## -0.91040 -0.18887  0.00019  0.16808  1.33149 
## 
## Coefficients:
##              Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)    
## (Intercept)  6.444537   0.037335  172.61   <2e-16 ***
## I(displ^2)  -0.038570   0.002214  -17.42   <2e-16 ***
## ---
## Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1
## 
## Residual standard error: 0.3324 on 232 degrees of freedom
## Multiple R-squared:  0.5668, Adjusted R-squared:  0.5649 
## F-statistic: 303.6 on 1 and 232 DF,  p-value: < 2.2e-16

heading: 2.4.1 Visualise the fit
text:
can visualise fit using procedure first augmenting linear model.two things note :name column predictor values violates usual naming conventions containing
brackets caret name wrapped backticksThe values column squared displacement valuesThis can verified comparing values lm_log_miles_aug values mpg2 â€”
rows reordered way , example, first row lm_log_miles_aug
corresponds first row mpg2We can visualise fit passing augmented model data ggplot():Obviously, great fit goal example!

heading: 3.1 Packages
text:
tidyr package another component package 
tidyverse contains functions cleaning 
reshaping data.penguins data set palmerpenguins
package used practice multiple linear regression.using package ellipse. package
contains functions drawing confidence regions associated estimates obtained linear
regression. Unlike code provided class drawing confidence regions took raw data
input, ellipse::ellipse.lm() function allow pass linear model object
instead. using ellipse package, however
need draw lines component confidence intervals (though 
difficult ).
code:
library(tibble)
library(dplyr)
library(ggplot2)
library(tidyr)
library(broom)
library(ellipse)
library(palmerpenguins)
theme_set(theme_bw())

heading: 3.2 The pipe
text:
pipe operator, %>%, can found package magrittr,
installed installed dplyr
package. dplyr loaded (calling library(dplyr)),
magrittr pipe also imported.pipe works taking result left passing first argument 
function right. pipe allows write cleaner code converting something like ::revealing underlying sequential logic workflow. Since pipe works taking 
result left passing first argument function right, use 
pipe wrangling data dplyr especially convenient 
dplyr data wrangling functions data frame argument 
first argument, cases, return data frame.example , first argument filter(), select(), mutate() data frame.
evaluation, function also returns data frame. Notice result piping data
frame functions, need actually specify going (since 
goes first argument default) need create extra variables intermediate
steps.
code:
mutate(select(filter(mydata, var1 > 5), var2, var3), var4 = var2 + sqrt(var3))
mydata %>%
  filter(var1 > 5) %>%
  select(var2, var3) %>%
  mutate(var4 = var2 + sqrt(var3))

heading: 3.3 Multiple linear regression â€” hypothesis testing
3.3.1 The penguins data
text:
Let us load penguins data set. variables interested working 
contain missing values. Immediately loading data, can pass drop_na()
function (tidyr) drop rows (observations) 
contain missing values.addition, also rename variables shorten code need 
type. can done piping data rename() function supplying name pairs
format new_name = old_name.
code:
penguins <- palmerpenguins::penguins %>%
  drop_na() %>%
  rename(
    bill_length = bill_length_mm,
    bill_depth = bill_depth_mm,
    flipper_length = flipper_length_mm,
    body_mass = body_mass_g
  )

penguins## # A tibble: 333 x 8
##    species island    bill_length bill_depth flipper_length body_mass sex    year
##    <fct>   <fct>           <dbl>      <dbl>          <int>     <int> <fct> <int>
##  1 Adelie  Torgersen        39.1       18.7            181      3750 male   2007
##  2 Adelie  Torgersen        39.5       17.4            186      3800 fema~  2007
##  3 Adelie  Torgersen        40.3       18              195      3250 fema~  2007
##  4 Adelie  Torgersen        36.7       19.3            193      3450 fema~  2007
##  5 Adelie  Torgersen        39.3       20.6            190      3650 male   2007
##  6 Adelie  Torgersen        38.9       17.8            181      3625 fema~  2007
##  7 Adelie  Torgersen        39.2       19.6            195      4675 male   2007
##  8 Adelie  Torgersen        41.1       17.6            182      3200 fema~  2007
##  9 Adelie  Torgersen        38.6       21.2            191      3800 male   2007
## 10 Adelie  Torgersen        34.6       21.1            198      4400 male   2007
## # ... with 323 more rows

heading: 3.3.2 Subsetting the data
text:
data set contains penguins three species across three islands:following example, let us focus penguins species Adelie island
Biscoe. can obtain subset penguins data using following code:(Note code , using two equal signs since making comparison 
setting values).
code:
penguins %>%
  distinct(species, island)## # A tibble: 5 x 2
##   species   island   
##   <fct>     <fct>    
## 1 Adelie    Torgersen
## 2 Adelie    Biscoe   
## 3 Adelie    Dream    
## 4 Gentoo    Biscoe   
## 5 Chinstrap Dream

adeliebiscoe <- penguins %>%
  filter(species == "Adelie", island == "Biscoe")

heading: 3.3.3 Visual check for linear relationship
text:
Suppose interested fitting model using body mass response bill length, bill
depth, flipper length predictors. building model, verify 
linear relationship response individual predictors.plots look okay. go ahead fit model.
code:
ggplot(adeliebiscoe, aes(x=bill_length, y=body_mass))+
  geom_point()
ggplot(adeliebiscoe, aes(x=bill_depth, y=body_mass))+
  geom_point()
ggplot(adeliebiscoe, aes(x=flipper_length, y=body_mass))+
  geom_point()

heading: 3.3.4 Fit the model
text: output, equation fitted line :\[\widehat{y}_{} \,=\, -6122 \,+\, 70.743x_{1,\,} \,+\, 165.196x_{2,\,} + 21.397x_{3,\,}\]:\(\widehat{y}_{}\) predicted body mass\(x_{1,\,}\) bill length\(x_{2,\,}\) bill depth\(x_{3,\,}\) flipper length
code:
ad_lm <- lm(body_mass ~ bill_length + bill_depth + flipper_length, data=adeliebiscoe)

summary(ad_lm)## 
## Call:
## lm(formula = body_mass ~ bill_length + bill_depth + flipper_length, 
##     data = adeliebiscoe)
## 
## Residuals:
##     Min      1Q  Median      3Q     Max 
## -836.50 -186.29   19.01  183.14  486.90 
## 
## Coefficients:
##                 Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)    
## (Intercept)    -6122.000   1341.697  -4.563 4.71e-05 ***
## bill_length       70.743     21.445   3.299 0.002046 ** 
## bill_depth       165.196     43.802   3.771 0.000526 ***
## flipper_length    21.397      7.262   2.947 0.005336 ** 
## ---
## Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1
## 
## Residual standard error: 298.8 on 40 degrees of freedom
## Multiple R-squared:  0.6508, Adjusted R-squared:  0.6246 
## F-statistic: 24.85 on 3 and 40 DF,  p-value: 3.048e-09

heading: 3.3.5 Fitting a model without an intercept
text:
default, linear models fitted intercept. can fit linear model without 
intercept adding + 0 - 1 formula specification (see Details section 
?lm). make hypothesis tests next section bit interesting,
let us remove intercept model just fit overwrite .shown Lab 1, can fitting brand new model:using update():Recall line code means (new) ad_lm constructed taking 
existing ad_lm updating formula. response variable remains (represented 
dot left tilde), predictors remain (represented dot 
right tilde) - 1 denotes want intercept.take look new model.Interestingly, removing intercept model, adjusted R-squared value went 
0.6246 0.9905 ðŸ‘€.
code:
ad_lm <- lm(body_mass ~ bill_length + bill_depth + flipper_length - 1, data=adeliebiscoe)
ad_lm <- update(ad_lm, formula = . ~ . - 1)
summary(ad_lm)## 
## Call:
## lm(formula = body_mass ~ bill_length + bill_depth + flipper_length - 
##     1, data = adeliebiscoe)
## 
## Residuals:
##     Min      1Q  Median      3Q     Max 
## -737.69 -296.78   41.82  236.37  769.39 
## 
## Coefficients:
##                Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)  
## bill_length      58.741     25.922   2.266   0.0288 *
## bill_depth      125.323     52.276   2.397   0.0212 *
## flipper_length   -4.635      5.471  -0.847   0.4018  
## ---
## Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1
## 
## Residual standard error: 363.9 on 41 degrees of freedom
## Multiple R-squared:  0.9912, Adjusted R-squared:  0.9905 
## F-statistic:  1536 on 3 and 41 DF,  p-value: < 2.2e-16

heading: 3.3.6 ANOVA with multiple linear regression models
text:
multiple linear regression, output resulting passing linear model anova() 
slightly different saw simple linear regression. simple linear regression,
wrapping linear model anova() produced "classic" \(F\)-table: sum squares 
first row SSR, sum squares second row SSE, single
\(F\)-value corresponding \(p\)-value.output, now three \(F\)-values three corresponding \(p\)-values! However, 
interpretation slightly different. sum squares column represents sequential
increase SSR (decrease SSE) adding variable model came . 
:sum squares bill_length row increase SSR (decrease SSE) 
including bill_length model (base model intercept)sum squares bill_depth row increase SSR (decrease SSE) 
including bill_depth model already includes bill_lengthThe sum squares flipper_length row increase SSR (decrease SSE) 
including flipper_length model already includes bill_length bill_depthThe sum squares Residual row SSE model includes 
bill_length, bill_depth, flipper_lengthUsing output , wish perform hypothesis test check whether subset 
parameters different zero, need extra math. since using R,
math! can perform partial \(F\)-tests interested constructing
reduced models (update() function becomes extremely handy).
code:
anova(ad_lm)## Analysis of Variance Table
## 
## Response: body_mass
##                Df    Sum Sq   Mean Sq   F value  Pr(>F)    
## bill_length     1 609528281 609528281 4601.6610 < 2e-16 ***
## bill_depth      1    683988    683988    5.1638 0.02837 *  
## flipper_length  1     95065     95065    0.7177 0.40182    
## Residuals      41   5430791    132458                      
## ---
## Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1

heading: 3.3.7 At least one parameter non-zero
text:
Suppose interested testing hypotheses:\[H_{0}: \beta_{1} \,=\, \beta_{2} \,=\, \beta_{3} \,=\, 0, \quad
H_{}: \text{least one non-zero}\]reduced model intercept-model passes origin.full model model predictors (ad_lm).test hypotheses, pass reduced full models anova():produces \(F\)-value 1535.8 numerator degrees freedom, 3, denominator degrees 
freedom, 41. need use values since \(p\)-value also given. Using 
significance level \(\alpha = 0.05\), since \(p\)-value less 0.05, reject null
hypothesis conclude least one parameters non-zero , 
consider constant \((Y \,=\, 0)\) model. important note hypothesis test tells us
least one parameter non-zero, tell us .hypothesis test null hypothesis parameters equal zero often known
test model usefulness. fail reject null hypothesis, suggests 
current model substantial improvement constant \((Y \,=\, c)\) model.
code:
ad_lm_origin_only <- update(ad_lm, formula = . ~ 0)
anova(ad_lm_origin_only, ad_lm)## Analysis of Variance Table
## 
## Model 1: body_mass ~ 1 - 1
## Model 2: body_mass ~ bill_length + bill_depth + flipper_length - 1
##   Res.Df       RSS Df Sum of Sq      F    Pr(>F)    
## 1     44 615738125                                  
## 2     41   5430791  3 610307334 1535.8 < 2.2e-16 ***
## ---
## Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1

heading: 3.3.8 Two parameters non-zero
text:
Suppose interested testing hypotheses:\[H_{0}: \beta_{2} \,=\, \beta_{3} \,=\, 0, \quad H_{}: \text{least one non-zero}\]reduced model model contains bill_length. can construct model using
update() either specifying variables want:variables wantTo test hypotheses, pass reduced full models anova():produces \(F\)-value 2.9407 numerator degrees freedom, 2, denominator degrees
freedom, 41. Using usual significance level \(\alpha = 0.05\), since \(p\)-value 
greater 0.05, fail reject null hypothesis conclude insufficient
evidence support claim least one \(\beta_{2}\) \(\beta_{3}\) non-zero.
code:
# Don't forget the no-intercept term!!
ad_lm1 <- update(ad_lm, formula = . ~ bill_length - 1)
ad_lm1 <- update(ad_lm, formula = . ~ . - bill_depth - flipper_length)
anova(ad_lm1, ad_lm)## Analysis of Variance Table
## 
## Model 1: body_mass ~ bill_length - 1
## Model 2: body_mass ~ bill_length + bill_depth + flipper_length - 1
##   Res.Df     RSS Df Sum of Sq      F  Pr(>F)  
## 1     43 6209844                              
## 2     41 5430791  2    779053 2.9407 0.06405 .
## ---
## Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1

heading: 3.3.9 One parameter non-zero
text:
Suppose interested testing hypotheses:\[H_{0}: \beta_{3} \,=\, 0, \quad H_{}: \beta_{3} \,\neq\, 0\]hypothesis can carried performing \(F\)-test \(t\)-test (\(t\)-test much
simpler). want perform \(F\)-test, take usual steps first constructing 
reduced model. reduced model model contains bill_length bill_depth. can
construct model using update() removing flipper_length.test hypotheses, pass reduced full models anova():produces \(F\)-value 0.7177 numerator degrees freedom, 1, denominator degrees
freedom, 41. Using usual significance level \(\alpha = 0.05\), since \(p\)-value 
greater 0.05, fail reject null hypothesis conclude insufficient
evidence support claim \(\beta_{3}\) different zero.testing single parameter non-zero, done \(t\)-test, whose corresponding \(p\)-value
read coefficient summary table.corresponding \(p\)-value \(t\)-test 0.402. Since \(p\)-value greater 0.05,
fail reject null hypothesis .
code:
ad_lm12 <- update(ad_lm, formula = . ~ . - flipper_length)
anova(ad_lm12, ad_lm)## Analysis of Variance Table
## 
## Model 1: body_mass ~ bill_length + bill_depth - 1
## Model 2: body_mass ~ bill_length + bill_depth + flipper_length - 1
##   Res.Df     RSS Df Sum of Sq      F Pr(>F)
## 1     42 5525856                           
## 2     41 5430791  1     95065 0.7177 0.4018
tidy(ad_lm)## # A tibble: 3 x 5
##   term           estimate std.error statistic p.value
##   <chr>             <dbl>     <dbl>     <dbl>   <dbl>
## 1 bill_length       58.7      25.9      2.27   0.0288
## 2 bill_depth       125.       52.3      2.40   0.0212
## 3 flipper_length    -4.64      5.47    -0.847  0.402

heading: 3.3.10 Caution â—
text:
Suppose output looked like:correct say:\(p\)-value test var2 different zero larger 0.05 fail reject
null hypothesis. \(p\)-value test var3 different zero larger 0.05 
fail reject null hypothesis. Therefore can simultaneously remove var2 var3 
model.\(p\)-value 0.497 corresponds testing var2 different zero, assuming var1 var3
included model. Similarly, \(p\)-value 0.885 corresponds testing var3 different
zero, assuming var1 var2 included model. Therefore proper procedure
using \(t\)-tests test single parameter non-zero, remove variable model
(assuming failed reject null hypothesis), refit new model without variable, 
perform second \(t\)-test.
code:
## # A tibble: 3 x 5
##   term  estimate std.error statistic p.value
##   <chr> <chr>    <chr>     <chr>       <dbl>
## 1 var1  ...      ...       ...        0.0001
## 2 var2  ...      ...       ...        0.497 
## 3 var3  ...      ...       ...        0.885

heading: 3.4 Multiple linear regression â€” working with matrices in R
3.5 Simple linear regression â€” simultaneous confidence regions
text:
Let us return rock data set consider simple linear regression model area 
response variable peri predictor.Suppose interested constructing 90% confidence region \((\beta_{0}, \beta_{1})\) 
individual 95% confidence intervals. can start obtaining path ellipse passing
linear model ellipse(). default confidence level ellipse 95% need 
make slight adjustment value level parameter. addition, ellipse() returns 
matrix coordinates path ellipse. Since passing coordinates 
path ellipse ggplot later, also convert data frame.values (Intercept) peri columns represent x- y-values, respectively,
path ellipse. Note ellipse() another example generic function. 
passing linear model object (object class lm) ellipse(), calls specific
ellipse.lm().Now path ellipse, also need obtain point
\((\widehat{\beta}_{0},\, \widehat{\beta}_{1})\), individual 95% confidence intervals 
\(\beta_{0}\) \(\beta_{1}\). can obtain passing linear model tidy.lm() 
specifying conf.int=TRUE obtain coefficient table corresponding 95% confidence
intervals.can begin plotting, data reshaping. Recall plotting 
ggplot(), need x-values one column y-values another column.need data frame estimate \(\beta_{0}\) one column estimate 
\(\beta_{1}\) another column.need data frame lower upper bounds confidence interval \(\beta_{0}\)
single column.need data frame lower upper bounds confidence interval \(\beta_{1}\)
single column.Now data "shape", can start building plot. plot constructed 
taking advantage fact every geom_*() layer data argument. means
can use different data set layer plot. Since common data
set common aesthetics shared layers, supply anything call
ggplot(). Try running code , layer layer, see plot constructed!
code:
data(rock)

slr_rock <- lm(area ~ peri, data=rock)
ellipse_path <- slr_rock %>%
  ellipse(level=0.90) %>%
  as_tibble()

ellipse_path## # A tibble: 100 x 2
##    `(Intercept)`  peri
##            <dbl> <dbl>
##  1         3305.  1.63
##  2         3239.  1.65
##  3         3174.  1.67
##  4         3107.  1.69
##  5         3041.  1.71
##  6         2974.  1.73
##  7         2908.  1.74
##  8         2842.  1.76
##  9         2777.  1.78
## 10         2714.  1.79
## # ... with 90 more rows

coef_table <- slr_rock %>%
  tidy(conf.int=TRUE)

coef_table## # A tibble: 2 x 7
##   term        estimate std.error statistic  p.value conf.low conf.high
##   <chr>          <dbl>     <dbl>     <dbl>    <dbl>    <dbl>     <dbl>
## 1 (Intercept)  3052.     477.         6.40 7.26e- 8  2092.     4012.  
## 2 peri            1.54     0.157      9.81 7.51e-13     1.23      1.86

coef_point <- coef_table %>%
  pivot_wider(id_cols=c(term, estimate), names_from=term, values_from=estimate)

coef_point## # A tibble: 1 x 2
##   `(Intercept)`  peri
##           <dbl> <dbl>
## 1         3052.  1.54

beta0 <- coef_table %>%
  slice(1) %>%
  pivot_longer(cols=contains("conf"))

beta0## # A tibble: 2 x 7
##   term        estimate std.error statistic      p.value name      value
##   <chr>          <dbl>     <dbl>     <dbl>        <dbl> <chr>     <dbl>
## 1 (Intercept)    3052.      477.      6.40 0.0000000726 conf.low  2092.
## 2 (Intercept)    3052.      477.      6.40 0.0000000726 conf.high 4012.

beta1 <- coef_table %>%
  slice(2) %>%
  pivot_longer(cols=contains("conf"))

beta1## # A tibble: 2 x 7
##   term  estimate std.error statistic  p.value name      value
##   <chr>    <dbl>     <dbl>     <dbl>    <dbl> <chr>     <dbl>
## 1 peri      1.54     0.157      9.81 7.51e-13 conf.low   1.23
## 2 peri      1.54     0.157      9.81 7.51e-13 conf.high  1.86

ggplot()+
  geom_vline(data=beta0, aes(xintercept=value), colour="#3366FF", lty=2)+
  geom_hline(data=beta1, aes(yintercept=value), colour="#3366FF", lty=2)+
  geom_point(data=coef_point, aes(x=`(Intercept)`, y=peri), colour="red")+
  geom_path(data=ellipse_path, aes(x=`(Intercept)`, y=peri))+
  labs(
    x="Intercept", y="Slope",
    caption="Solid line represents 90% confidence region. Dashed lines represent 95% confidence intervals."
  )
